message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug's selective inhibition of late sodium influx into cardiac myocytes suggests it can increase the heart's efficiency in using oxygen, thus increasing oxygen efficiency. The inhibition of fatty acid degradation does not suggest options B, C or D.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Refractory angina pectoris suggests a lack of sufficient oxygen delivery to the heart. Inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes can decrease oxygen demand and increase oxygen efficiency. The other options are not related to the drug's mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Refractory angina pectoris is caused by decreased oxygen supply to the heart. Inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes can help increase oxygen efficiency. The other options are not related to the mechanism of action of the drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Selectively inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes can improve cardiac contractility and oxygen efficiency. None of the other options are related to this mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes increases intracellular calcium concentration, which can lead to decreased oxygen efficiency and ischemia. Therefore, inhibiting this influx will likely result in increased oxygen efficiency. The other options are not directly related to the mechanism of action of the drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Selectively inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes can increase oxygen efficiency by reducing myocardial ischemia, which is useful in treating refractory angina pectoris. The other options are not related to the mechanism of action of the drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Refractory angina pectoris is due to reduced oxygen supply or increased oxygen demand. By selectively inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes, this drug can decrease the oxygen demand of the heart and increase oxygen efficiency. Fatty acid degradation inhibition is not related to any of the options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Refractory angina pectoris indicates a lack of oxygen supply to the heart, so by selectively inhibiting the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes, the drug can increase oxygen efficiency. None of the other options are related to angina pectoris or sodium ion inhibition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug selectively inhibits the late influx of sodium ions into cardiac myocytes, which is expected to improve oxygen efficiency in the heart. The other options are not related to the mechanism of action of the drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Refractory angina pectoris is caused by reduced oxygen supply to the heart, and increased oxygen efficiency can help reduce the symptoms. None of the other options are associated with the mechanisms of the drug described.
